results.title: Carrington
results.creator_credit: Christopher Hampton, John McGrath, Ronald Shedlo and Dora Productions
results.brief_description: Dora Carrington (Emma Thompson) devotes her life to writer Lytton Strachey (Jonathan Pryce) a tall, thin, bearded bachelor and member of London’s famed Bloomsbury artistic set. Even though their desire for each other was strong, their relationship was purely based on friendship, a bond that lives until the very end. This is one of the most unusual love stories you will ever see.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher Hampton, John McGrath, Ronald Shedlo and Dora Productions

results.title: Casterton lights up!
results.brief_description:
Casterton is a small rural town roughly half way between Melbourne and Adelaide, in far western Victoria. Like many smaller rural communities, Casterton has a rich agricultural history that claims not only to being the birthplace of the Kelpie but the first permanent inland Victorian settlement.
Due to a loss of both government and local industries during the nineties, Casterton found itself struggling to maintain its population. In April 1995, a public meeting was called to establish a survival plan. Attended by a hundred or so locals, the meeting produced a number of community initiatives including the developmentof a local phenomenon into a public festival.
In the eight years since, the annual Christmas lights festival has grown into the most important event on Casterton’s social calender. Today, two thirds of all homes in Casterton are lit each Christmas with up to 10,000 visitors passing through the town each December to take part in the nightly lights tours run by the local Lions Club
Casterton Lights Up! is an independently produced community documentary project written, directed, produced and funded by Melbourne Based filmmaker Glen Moore. The project was developed with the assistance and keen support of the Casterton community and aims to highlight the importance of community connectedness and spirit to the survival of small rural communities.

results.title: Casque D'or = Golden Marie
results.creator_credit: Jacques Becker, Michel Safre, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description:
n turn-of-the-century Paris an honest carpenter, is drawn into a world of pimps, prostitutes and petty crooks (‘Apaches’ as they were called at the time), because of his passion for ganster’s moll Marie. Becker’s lovingly recreated Paris of the past almost equals the radiance of Renoir, both father and son. [Becker worked as Jean Renoir’s assistant] Despite the ‘crime passionnel’ plot, the film is an affirmation of love and friendship. ‘Casque d’Or’ is primarily a film of personalities, but it is also a visual tour de force: a dance, brawl in the backyard, an awakening in the countryside, Manda’s arrival at the guillotine supported by a priest - these images are like magazine covers. This visual enchantment confirms me in my conviction that cinema is a popular art, and that it deceives itself when it tries to bring the paintings of the masters to life. ‘Casque d’Or’, at times funny, at times tragic, proves that we can surpass parody; we can look at the picturesque and bloody past and evoke it with tenderness and violence by means of a refined use of tone changes”. Reference: Francois Truffaut. ‘The films in my life’. Da Capo Press, 1994. Completed in 1951, ‘Casque D’Or’ was a failure on its first release, but then built up an excellent word-of-mouth reputation abroad. Awards: BAFTA Awards 1952: Best Actress for Simone Signoret.

Credits: Producer, Robert and Raymond Hakim, Michel Safre; director, Jacques Becker ; writers, Jacques Becker, Jacques Companeez ; photography, Robert Le Febvre ; music, Georges van Parys ; editor, Marguerite Renoir ; art direction, Jean d’Eaubonne.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Serge Reggianni, Claude Dauphin, Raymond Bussieres, Loleh Bellon, William Sabatier, Dominique Davray, Jean Clarieux.

results.title: Casino [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on material gathered for a non-fiction book by Nicholas Pileggi, “Casino” takes an in depth look at the behind the scenes world of a casino whilst following the history of the mob in Las Vegas. It is 1973 and Sam Rothstein (Robert de Niro) is sent by the mob to manage the Tangiers casino. Sam’s childhood friend Nicky Santoro (Joe Pesci), follows him to Vegas whereupon he’s hired to enforce mob control. Sam’s successful running of the Tangiers is soon jeopardised by Nicky’s hotheaded thuggery and the explosive behaviour of his coke-addicted wife Ginger (Sharon Stone). “Casino” is Martin Scorsese’s tribute to a Las Vegas now gone. The film is marked with Scorsese’s usual visual flair and kinetic style, with a deadpan voiceover narration from Sam and occasionally Nicky. Sharon Stone gives a knockout performance as the unstable Ginger.

results.title: Casablanca
results.creator_credit: Michael Curtiz, Hal B. Wallis and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Popular wartime film made in the classic Warner Studios gritty style by director Michael Curtiz, with a wonderful cast including Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman playing ill-fated lovers Rick and Ilsa. The story is set in Rick’s Café in Vichy controlled Casablanca which has become a gateway to America for desperate refugees escaping wartorn Europe. Others in the cast include Paul Henreid, Sydney Greenstreet, Peter Lorre, Conrad Veidt and Claude Rains who delivers some of the most memorable lines in a particularly witty script by Phillip and Julius Epstein and Howard Koch.

results.title: Carving Techniques and Projects
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the basics of gouge and chisel work, discussing the choice of tools, ideas and how to adjust designs. Shows how to carve the hallmark of 18th century furniture: the classic scallop shell.

results.title: Caroline Cherie = Dear Caroline
results.creator_credit: Richard Pottier, Paul Cadeac and Alain Poire
results.brief_description:
Caroline de Bievres celebrates her 16th birthday on 14 July 1789. While the Parisians storm the Bastille, Caroline experiences love with Gaston de Sallanches. Sent to Paris by her parents, she discovers that Gaston is already married.

Credits: Producer, Alain Poire, Paul Cadeac ; director, Richard Pottier ; writer, Jean Anouilh ; photography, Maurice Barry ; music, Georges Auric ; art director, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Martine Carol, Jacques Dacqmine, Pierre Cressoy, Jacques Clancy, Marie Dea, Daniele Seller, Paul Bernard, Alfred Adam, Raymond Souplex, Marthe Mercadier, Nadine Alari, Yvonne de Bray, Marie Dea, Olivier Hussenot.

results.title: Carve a Ball and Claw Foot
results.brief_description: Learn how to scale the ball-and-claw to furniture plan, how to machine stock to yield a graceful bandsaw cabriole leg ready for carving, how to lay out form, cut-in with a mallet and gouge and shape the dragon’s claw for a vigorous looking grip, how to carve efficiently, keeping tools sharp as you work.

results.title: Cartoon classics of the 30's
results.brief_description: A historic collection of classic animated cartoons from the 1930s including two very famous and much loved characters, Felix the Cat (The Goose that laid the golden egg) and Daffy Duck. Entertaining family viewing but also a fascinating look back at animation styles and techniques of the era. NB: Quality of sound and color is variable.

results.title: Caroline
results.creator_credit: Clement Perron, Georges Dufaux and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: To the public she is the pleasant, never-ruffled handler of everyone’s complaints at the telephone company. But behind her calm exterior the film reveals her doubts about her personal life, the domestic world of husband and child.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Clement Perron, Georges Dufaux and National Film Board of Canada
